questions.text: A patient living in a tropical climate presents to you with minute papules present in large numbers, especially over the flexures. They cause intense discomfort causing unbearable prickling sensation. You suspect miliaria.  All of the following measures would help the patient except:
questions.solution:
Tight clothing is not recommended in miliaria, the patients need to avoid tight or excessive clothing.

Miliaria is a condition that arises due to the occlusion of eccrine sweat glands. This causes leakage of sweat into the epidermis or dermis.

The mainstay of management is to avoid further sweating. The following precautions are advised to the patient:

• Control local environment- remove excess bedding, use fans and air conditioners
• Cooling the skin- damp compresses, cool showers
• Avoid tight or excessive clothing

Vitamin C supplements were found to decrease the severity of miliaria.

Related Pearl: Different types of miliaria

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions.

Based on the level of blockade it is differentiated into

  • Miliaria Crystallina- Stratum corneum
  • Miliaria Rubra - Malpighian Layer
  • Miliaria profunda - Dermoepidermal junction

Pathophysiology:

  • The first event may be an increase in the skin flora, perhaps with Staphylococcus epidermidis being responsible for producing an extracellular polysaccharide substance or slime that blocks the lumen of the sweat duct.
  • The parakeratotic plugs, a notable feature of the later stages of the disease, are not the primary cause of the obstruction but arise in the repair process, and further aggravate the obstruction.
  • Leakage of sweat into the epidermis is responsible for the final production of the lesions, and for their further aggravation.
  • Miliaria crystallina occurs commonly in infants due to a delay in the development of patency in the sweat ducts.

Clinical features:

  • Miliaria crystallina: Clear, thin‐walled vesicles, 1–2 mm in diameter without an inflammatory areola, are usually symptomless and develop in crops, mainly on the trunk. In persistent febrile illnesses, recurrent crops may occur. The vesicles soon rupture and are followed by superficial, branny desquamation.

 

  • Miliaria rubra: Typical lesions develop on the body, especially in areas of friction with clothing, and in flexures. The lesions are uniformly minute erythematous papules, which may be present in very large numbers. Characteristically, the lesions produce intense discomfort in the form of an unbearable pricking sensation. Relief is often instantaneous when the stimulus to sweating is abolished by a cool shower. In infants, lesions commonly appear on the occluded skin of the neck, groins and axillae, but also occur elsewhere.

 

 

  • Miliaria profunda: This nearly always follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra, and is common only in the tropics. The lesions are easily missed. The affected skin is covered with pale, firm papules 1–3 mm across, especially on the body, but sometimes also on the limbs. There is no itching or discomfort from the lesions.

 

Treatment:

  • First line
    • Control local environment (remove excess bedding, fans, air
    conditioning)
    • Cool the skin (damp compresses, cool showers)
    • Avoid tight or excessive clothing
  • Second line
    • Menthol (e.g. 0.5% menthol in aqueous cream)
    • Topical antibiotics if there is secondary infection
    • Mild topical steroids
  • Third line
    • Removal to cooler climate
    • Prophylactic oral vitamin C

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman delivered a baby with the following anomaly. Further investigations revealed multiple anomalies like tracheoesophageal fistula, vertebral,  anal, cardiac, renal, and arterial defects. Which of the following drug taken by the mother is most likely to be responsible for the baby's condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a newborn with radial aplasia of the right arm. This feature, along with the given clinical presentation, describes VACTERL defects. This condition is associated with maternal intake of statins. 

VACTERL defects is an acronym for a group of congenital malformations which characteristically include:

  • Vertebral defects
  • Anal atresia
  • Cardiovascular malformation
  • Tracheoesophageal fistula with esophageal atresia
  • Radial/Renal dysplasia
  • Limb anomalies

Genito-urinary anomalies (ambiguous genitalia, genitourinary fistula, cryptorchidism) and other system anomalies like facial asymmetry, external ear malformation, etc. can also be found in these patients.

VACTERL defects have been associated with maternal exposure to statins, doxorubicin, and lead. They are also associated with maternal diabetes.

Other options:

Option A: Penicillamine causes cutis laxa syndrome. Cutis laxa is a group of rare connective tissue disorders in which the skin becomes inelastic and hangs loosely in folds. Maternal exposure to penicillamine was found to be associated with cutis laxa in infants.

The image below shows cutis laxa:

 

Option B: Vitamin D causes supravalvular aortic stenosis.

Option C: Lithium causes Ebstein anomaly. 

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
ACE inhibitors and ARBs

Hypoplasia of organs, anuria, irreversible renal failure
Carbimazole and Methimazole  

Choanal atresia, aplasia cutis, tracheoesophageal fistula and fetal goiter
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: A 35-year-old man who underwent surgery for appendicitis was given a high dose of opioids postoperatively to relieve the pain. But within a few hours,  a fall in SpO2 and respiratory rate were noted. Which of the following drugs has been accepted as standard therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of opioid-induced respiratory depression and naloxone has been accepted as standard therapy in this patient.

Opioid-induced respiratory depression is mediated by the action on µ receptors in the brainstem respiratory centers. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist, which can reverse the respiratory depression induced by opioids.

Respiratory depression can be prolonged when opioids are taken with other CNS depressant substances like alcohol, barbiturates, benzodiazepines, inhalational anesthetics, and other sedative-hypnotics.

However, droperidol, scopolamine, and clonidine do not increase the respiratory depressant effects of fentanyl or other opioids.

Related Pearl: Classification of opioids based on their action on opioid receptors

Related Pearl: Classification of Opioids

Naturally Occurring:

  • Morphine

  • Papaverine

Semisynthetic:

  • Heroin (diacetyl morphine)
  • Dihydromorphone, morphinone
  • Thebaine derivatives (e.g., etorphine, buprenorphine)

Synthetic:

  • Morphinan series (e.g., levorphanol, butorphanol)
  • Diphenylpropylamine series (e.g., methadone)
  • Benzomorphan series (e.g., pentazocine)
  • Phenylpiperidine series (e.g., meperidine, fentanyl, sufentanil, alfentanil, remifentanil)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of excess uncontrollable worry over daily life activities, finance, and his health over the past 2 years. Because of this, he feels restless most of the time. He also complains of fatigue and disturbed sleep. Which of the following is the first-line drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms favor a diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder and the first-line drug used in this patient is selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) i.e sertraline.

Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) presents as excessive anxiety and worry about a number of events or activities for at least 6 months. Anxiety and worry are associated with three (or more) of the following symptoms: 

  • Restlessness
  • Being easily fatigued
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

First-line drugs for GAD are SSRIs and SNRIs. The commonly used SSRIs include sertraline, citalopram, and paroxetine, whereas, the commonly used SNRIs include venlafaxine and duloxetine. Second-line drugs include benzodiazepines, atypical antipsychotics like quetiapine, anticonvulsant like pregabalin, and other psychotropics like buspirone.

Note: It is advisable to start SSRIs along with benzodiazepines and taper benzodiazepines use after 2-3 weeks.

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
1. Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

Immediate: Benzodiazepines
Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady who is a known diabetic has had right shoulder pain for the past 7 months. She had pain initially mainly on external rotation along with restricted movements. Now, her pain has gradually decreased but she still complains of a stiff shoulder. You diagnose her with adhesive capsulitis. What stage of adhesive capsulitis is this patient in?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of decrease in pain and complaints of stiffness in the shoulder joint indicate stage II of adhesive capsulitis/frozen shoulder.

Frozen shoulder is a disorder characterized by progressive pain and stiffness of the shoulder, which usually resolves spontaneously. The condition is particularly associated with diabetes, Dupuytren’s contracture, hyperlipidemia, thyroid disorders, cardiac disease, and hemiplegia. X-ray of the shoulder is usually normal, with some cases showing sclerosis on the outer edge of the greater tuberosity.

Reeves classified the frozen shoulder into three stages:

  • Stage I (Stage of pain): In this stage patients usually complain of acute pain with decreased movements (external rotation is most affected followed by the abduction and then forward flexion; internal rotation is the least affected). This stage lasts for 10-36 weeks
  • Stage II: The stage of stiffness where pain gradually decreases and patients complain of the stiff shoulder. This lasts for 4 to 12 months.
  • Stage III: The stage of recovery, the patient will have no pain and the movements have recovered except that the movements are never regained back to normal. It usually lasts for 6 months to 2 years.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed neonate in his 4th week of life was found to have jaundice. His stools are yellow and his urine is pale straw yellow-colored. He is otherwise well. Blood tests show unconjugated bilirubinemia. What could be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given child is exclusively breastfed, whose stools and urine appear normal, along with unconjugated bilirubinemia suggests breast milk jaundice.

Breast milk jaundice is uncommon and is seen in exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 3-4 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain pregnanediol and β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption. Persistently high bilirubin levels may require phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding.

Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals.

Other options: 

Options A and D- Biliary atresia and neonatal cholestasis have conjugated bilirubinemia.

Option B- Erythroblastosis fetalis have unconjugated bilirubinemia and it is seen in the first 24 hours of life.

Related Pearl: Hyperbilirubinemia- Causes

 Predominantly Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia  Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Excess production of bilirubin

  

Hemolytic anemias

Biliary tract obstruction

Resorption of blood from internal hemorrhage (e.g., alimentary tract bleeding, hematomas)

 Biliary tract diseases like primary biliary cirrhosis and primary sclerosing cholangitis

Ineffective erythropoiesis (e.g., pernicious anemia, thalassemia)

Dubin Johnson syndrome

Reduced hepatic uptake

Rotor syndrome

Drug interference with membrane carrier systems

 Benign recurrent intrahepatic cholestasis

Some cases of Gilbert syndrome

 Progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis

Impaired bilirubin conjugation

  

Physiologic jaundice of the newborn (decreased UGT1A1 activity, decreased excretion)

  

Breast milk jaundice (β-glucuronidases in milk)

  

Genetic deficiency of UGT1A1 activity (Crigler-Najjar syndrome types I and II)

  

Gilbert syndrome

  

Diffuse hepatocellular disease (e.g., viral or drug-induced hepatitis, cirrhosis)

questions.text: A multiparous woman has a previous history of birth trauma with injury to the uterosacral and cardinal ligaments. According to DeLancey's classification, which level of uterine support is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
According to DeLancey's classification, level 1 of uterine support is affected in this patient as the uterosacral and cardinal ligaments are injured.

DeLancey introduced three-level systems of genital tract supports:

  • Level I includes uterosacral and cardinal ligaments. Damage to these ligaments leads to uterine descent, enterocoele, and vault prolapse.
  • Level II includes pelvic fascia, paracolpos,arcus tendineus, pubocervical, and rectovaginal fascia. Damage to these structures leads to cystocele and rectocele.
  • Level III includes levator ani muscle and its damage leads to urethrocele, gaping introitus, and deficient perineum.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

 

Related Pearl: Supports of the uterus

A. Primary supports

  • Muscular or active support of the uterus:
    • Pelvic diaphragm
    • Perineal body
    • Urogenital diaphragm
  • Ligamentous (fibromuscular or mechanical) support:
    • Transverse cervical ligaments of Mackenrodt or cardinal ligament
    • Uterosacral ligament
    • Round ligament of the uterus
    • Pubocervical ligament
    • Uterine axis

B. Secondary supports formed by peritoneal ligaments:

  • Broad ligament
  • Uterovesical fold of peritoneum
  • Rectovaginal fold of peritoneum

questions.text: A child, previously diagnosed with an endocrine tumor, presented with conjugate eye movements and myoclonus. Which of the following tumors must have led to this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of conjugate eye movements and myoclonus indicates opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome (OMS). It is associated with neuroblastoma.

Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome is rapid, conjugate eye nystagmus with involuntary spasms of the limbs, and is also called dancing eyes-dancing feet syndrome.

Causes:
  • When opsoclonus and myoclonus occur together, the cause is a tumor until proven otherwise.
  • In approximately 50 percent of affected children, neuroblastoma is responsible for the symptoms associated with OMS.
  • In other cases, the disorder has been designated ‘idiopathic’ or attributed to various mostly viral infections, such as Coxsackievirus B3 or St. Louis encephalitis virus

The main treatment for OMS is early and sufficient immunotherapy with the goal of gaining a durable complete neurological remission. If a tumor is present, surgical resection is standard. 

Neuroblastoma is a malignancy arising from the neuroblast cells in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia. It typically presents as an abdominal or paravertebral mass. The etiology is unknown, however, familial predisposition is associated with mutations in the ALK gene (anaplastic lymphoma kinase gene).

It is predominantly seen in children less than 5 years of age. Clinical features include mass effect due to the tumor (spinal cord compression, bowel obstruction) and metastatic disease. Raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymoses) are seen in neuroblastoma due to orbital metastasis. In neonates, multiple cutaneous metastases cause deep blue discoloration of the skin called blueberry muffin baby. Children may present with fever, bone pains, and failure to thrive. Elevated blood pressure is seen due to increased levels of catecholamines in the blood. 

Histology shows small round blue cells with dark nuclei and scanty cytoplasm and Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. Urine vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA) are elevated. 

The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumor and adjuvant chemotherapy. The drugs used from chemotherapy are carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, etoposide, and doxorubicin.

The gif below shows opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome:

questions.text: A middle-aged man complains of the frequent dropping of handheld things and tripping while walking. On examination, the patient appeared as shown in the image below. Strength is 4/5 in the intrinsic muscles of the hand. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing the patient with frontal balding, and a typical hatchet-faced appearance are suggestive of type 1 myotonic dystrophy.

Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is caused due to CTG trinucleotide repeat in DMPK gene on chromosome 19. It is mainly of two types: myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1), and myotonic dystrophy type 2 (DM2).

Clinically, patients will have a typical hatchet-faced appearance due to wasting of the temporal and masseter muscles. Frontal baldness and a high-arched palate are also seen. 

It is associated with weakness in the distal muscles of the wrist, fingers, and foot. Involvement of the palatal, pharyngeal, and tongue muscles causes dysarthria and dysphagia. Involvement of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles leads to respiratory insufficiency. Proximal muscles remain unaffected.

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. ECG shows conduction abnormalities in the form of first-degree heart block. Electromyography may show myotonia in DM1, however, it is patchy in DM2. Creatine kinase levels in the serum may be normal or mildly elevated.

The histopathological finding of muscle biopsy in both DM1, and DM2, shows internalized nuclei seen in individual muscle fibers, and the presence of several atrophic fibers with pyknotic nuclear clumps.

Treatment is mainly symptomatic. However, mexiletine is indicated for both DM1 and DM2 help in reducing myotonia.

Other options:

Options A and B: Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies present with proximal muscle weakness. These are x-linked recessive dystrophies. Therefore, family history would reveal that mainly men in the family are affected.

Option D: In Pompe's disease or acid maltase deficiency is a glycogen storage disease. Affected children present with hypotonia, myocardiopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Respiratory muscle weakness leading to ventilatory insufficiency may be a prominent feature.

questions.text: During a study, you are collecting, reviewing, and presenting information to answer a research question while making sure they meet specific inclusion and exclusion criteria. What is this process?
questions.solution:
The process of collecting, reviewing, and presenting information to answer a research question while making sure they meet specific inclusion and exclusion criteria is called a systematic review.

 Steps of a systematic review:

  • Formulate the review question
  • Define inclusion and exclusion criteria to choose studies
  • Select studies and extract data
  • Analyze and interpret data

Other options:

Option A: Cohort study is a prospective study that involves the follow-up of a cohort (a group of people) with risk factors to check if they develop an outcome or disease.

Option B: Meta-analysis is a quantitative method to study the previous research studies of a selected topic/ research question. It uses statistical methods to summarise results and its validity relies upon the quality of the studies used and reviewed.

Option C: A randomized control trial is an experimental study in which an intervention (maybe addition or omission of drug or actions) is given to a group of people participating in the study and compared to another group of individuals with similar characteristics who are not given that intervention to be studied.

Related Pearl: Meta-analysis in Research

  • Meta-analysis is a set of statistical techniques for combining quantitative results from multiple studies to produce a summary of empirical knowledge on a given topic.
  • It refers to a method of systematic review.
  • It is one of the most relevant methods in evidence-based medicine and ranks high on the evidence pyramid.
  • Limitations
    • When testing is done before hypothesis generation, spurious results are found.
    • Sample size may be misrepresentative.
    • Publication bias due to suppression of some important information leading to file drawer effect.
    • Heterogeneity of studies may force mashing together of disparate effects and lead to selection bias. This is also called apples and oranges effect.
    • Dissimilarities in control groups.
    • Its validity is dependent on the quality of the systematic review and the original data used.

Related Pearl: Evidence Pyramid in Research

The evidence pyramid gives the hierarchy or ranking of evidence from different types of methods used in research.

Animal research ranks the lowest, while meta-analysis ranks the highest and gives the best evidence.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the newborn eye?

choices.text: A refractive error of -2D is present

questions.solution:
The newborn eye is usually hypermetropic by +2 to +3 D.

Features of the eye in a newborn:

  • The anteroposterior diameter of the eyeball is about 70% of the adult size- 16.5 mm. Adult size is attained by 7–8 years of age.
  • The corneal diameter is approximately 10 mm. Adult size (11.7 mm) is attained by 2 years of age.
  • The anterior chamber has a narrow-angle and is shallow.
  • The pupil is small and does not dilate completely.
  • The lens has a spherical shape at birth and has infantile nucleus.
  • The retina is fully differentiated, except for the macular area. The differentiation of macula occurs 4–6 months after birth.
  • The myelination of optic nerve fibers reaches upto the lamina cribrosa.
  • The newborn is usually hypermetropic by +2 to +3 D.
  • The orbit has more divergence (50°) as compared to adult (45°).
  • The lacrimal gland is underdeveloped and tears are not secreted.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient experienced a complete loss of vision following a functional endoscopic sinus surgery for chronic ethmoidal sinusitis. Which of the following air cells are in close anatomical proximity to the structure most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
The structure most likely injured in this patient is the optic nerve and the Onodi cell is in close proximity to it.

Onodi cell is an anatomical variant, in which the posterior ethmoidal cells enlarge and extend into the sphenoid bone laterally and superior to the sphenoid sinus. The sphenoid sinus is in close relation to the optic nerve and sometimes the carotid artery. Therefore, while removing posterior ethmoidal cells during endoscopic surgery, the presence of Onodi cells increases the risk to the optic nerve.

Ethmoidal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the lateral mass of the ethmoid bone. They are bound medially by the lateral nasal wall, laterally by a thin plate of bone called the lamina papyracea, and superiorly by an extension of the orbital plate of the frontal bone. 

The ethmoid sinusoidal air cells range from 3 to 18 in number and are divided into anterior and posterior groups by a basal lamina.

  • Anterior cells- They open into the middle meatus. They contain-
    • Agger nasi cells - Present in the agger nasi ridge
    • Ethmoid bulla - Forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris
    • Supraorbital cells
    • Frontoethmoid cells- In the area of the frontal recess
    • Haller cells - In the floor of the orbit. Lies in the roof of the maxillary sinus, and enlargement may prevent drainage of the maxillary sinus.
  • Posterior cells - They open into the superior or the supreme meatus. Occasionally, they may also open directly into the sphenoid sinus. They contain about 1-7 cells, the most important one being the Onodi cells. Onodi cells extend as far back as 1.5 centimetres from their anterior wall.

The image shown below shows the location of the Onodi cell or the sphenoethmoidal cell.

Haller cell (infraorbital ethmoidal air cell) which is an anterior ethmoidal air cell that pneumatizes into the roof of maxillary sinus or orbital floor above the maxillary sinus ostium.

questions.text: A surgeon applies a very tight plaster cast on patient’s leg and asks the patient to inform if he develops any numbness. The patient develops numbness but does not inform the doctor immediately. Next day, when the patient informs the doctor, the doctor says he is too busy to remove the cast. After a few days, the patient develops a permanent injury. The doctor is held guilty under:
questions.solution:
This is a case of last clear chance doctrine and the doctor is held guilty.

In this case:

  • The doctor showed negligence by applying tight plaster cast, however, gave proper instructions to the patient.
  • The patient has neglected by not informing the doctor immediately after he developed numbness.
  • When the patient informed the doctor the next day, the doctor still had a chance to remove the cast and prevent permanent injury. But the doctor again neglected and thus missed the last clear chance.

So, the doctor cannot plead for contributory negligence and will be held guilty under the last clear chance doctrine.

Other options:

Option D: Medical maloccurrence is a defence against negligence for doctors. In certain cases, despite proper medical skill, attention, and care, the patient may fail to respond or suffer from the adverse effects of drugs. 

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug does not act via inhibition of sodium channels?
questions.solution:
Vigabatrin acts by inhibiting GABA transaminase that enhances the effect of GABA by reducing its metabolism.

Classification of antiepileptics according to their action:

Prolongation of Na+ channel inactivation: 

Enhance fast inactivation: These act by blocking the propagation of action potential and stabilization of neural membranes. They also reduce the neurotransmitter release, focal firing, and seizure spread.

  • Phenytoin
  • Carbamazepine
  • Sodium valproate
  • Lamotrigine
  • Topiramate

Enhance slow inactivation: These increase spike frequency adaptation and reduce action potential bursts, focal firing, and seizure spread. Also, these drugs stabilize the neural membrane.

  • Lacosamide

Facilitation of GABA-mediated Cl- channel opening

  • Barbiturate
  • Benzodiazepine
  • Vigabatrin
  • Sodium valproate
  • Gabapentin
  • Tiagabine

Calcium channel blockers: The N- and P- types of calcium channel blocking result in decreased neurotransmitter release. And blocking of T-type calcium channel leads to a decrease in slow depolarization and spike-wave discharge.

  • Ethosuximide
  • Sodium valproate
  • Lamotrigine

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of common anti-epileptics

Mechanism of action of some common antiepileptics:

Mechanism of action Antiepileptics

  • Carbamazepine
  • Oxcarbazepine
  • Eslicarbazepine
  • Lamotrigine     
  • Topiramate      
  • Felbamate
  • Valproate
  • Rufinamide
Calcium-channel blockers
  • Valproate
  • Lamotrigine   
  • Ethosuximide

  • Benzodiazepine
  • Phenobarbital
  • Felbamate
  • Primidone
  • Topiramate
  • Carbamazepine
  • Oxcarbazepine
  • Stiripentol
  • Clobazam
GABA uptake inhibitors

  • Vigabatrin

  • Levetiracetam
  • Brivaracetam
NMDA receptor antagonist
  • Felbamate
AMPA/Kainate receptor antagonist
  • Phenobarbital
  • Topiramate
  • Perampanel
HCN channel activity enhancers

Inhibitors of brain carbonic anhydrase
  • Acetazolamide
  • Zonisamide
  • Topiramate
Potassium-channel openers
  • Retigabine
  • Topiramate

questions.text: An infant presented with skin lesions as shown in the image below. He had infected diaper rash and fever for the past 3 days. On examination, the lesions are positive for Nikolsky sign. Investigations revealed gram-positive cocci in clusters. Identify the skin protein targeted by the exotoxin of this organism.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS). The skin protein targeted by the exotoxins in this condition is desmoglein 1. 

Also known as Ritter's syndrome, staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is an exfoliative dermatosis caused by exfoliative toxins A and B released by Staphylococcus. The exotoxins bind to a molecule within the desmosome called desmoglein 1 and cause splitting of the epidermis is present between the granular and spinous layers which ultimately leads to painful raw areas.

It mostly affects children under the age of 6 years and newborns.  

Clinically, patients usually develop fever and skin tenderness following a localized staphylococcal infection. Widespread erythematous eruption is seen, more in flexural areas.  A positive Nikolsky sign is seen with dislodgement of the intact superficial epidermis by a shearing force. The mucosa is usually not involved. 

Histological examination of the sloughed skin shows a number of epithelial cells with large nuclei but inflammatory cells or bacteria are not seen, as the pathology is mediated by toxins and not the bacteria itself. Gram-positive cocci may be seen in the initial site of infection.

Treatment includes antibiotic therapy with first-line drugs such as flucoxacillin, clindamycin, and tigecycline or based on the antibiotic sensitivity tests. 

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Staphylococcus

Staphylococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Furuncle/boil- Infection of the hair follicle.

The given image shows a furuncle:

 

b. Carbuncle: A cluster of several furuncles:

The given image shows a carbuncle:

 

c. Bullous impetigo: Results in large blisters called bullae, usually seen in areas with skin folds such as armpits, groin, buttocks, etc.

The given image shows ruptured bullous impetigo:

 

d. Cellulitis: It is a rapidly spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, usually associated with wounds, incisions, burns, etc.

The given image shows cellulitis following an abrasion. The red streaks indicate the involvement of the lymphatics:

 

e. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliating toxin that causes peeling of the skin.

The given image shows SSSS:

 

Note: The conditions shown above are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus. It is important to remember that they may also be caused by other bacteria. Cellulitis is more commonly caused by Streptococcus.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient with a history of smoking presented with a painless palpable mass in the parotid region. The biopsy of the mass is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation and histopathological slide showing epithelial elements with lymphoid infiltration are suggestive of a Warthin tumor (papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum) of the parotid gland.

Warthin tumor is the second most common salivary gland neoplasm. It is seen in elderly male smokers. It is a benign, well-encapsulated cystic tumor.

The gross appearance of these tumors shows round to oval encapsulated masses, easily palpable in the superficial parotid. Transection reveals a pale grey surface punctuated by cleft-like spaces filled with mucinous or serous secretions.

Histologically, the tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells, with an inner columnar layer and an outer cuboidal layer.

Other options:

Option A: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is poorly encapsulated infiltrative carcinoma involving minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells, organized in a cribriform growth pattern, resembling swiss cheese. The image is shown below.

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Many are associated with a balanced (11;19) (q21;p13) chromosomal translocation. Histology shows mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles. Image is shown below.

Option D: Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms. The parotid gland is most commonly involved. They are benign tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. Image is shown below.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: Which amino acid  will yield only acetyl-CoA on oxidation and  cannot be used for gluconeogenesis  ?
questions.solution:
Leucine and lysine yield only acetyl-CoA on oxidation (ketogenesis), and hence, they cannot be used for gluconeogenesis. These two (lysine and leucine) are the only purely ketogenic amino acids.

Four other amino acids, namely, phenylalanine, tyrosine, tryptophan, and isoleucine, give rise to both acetyl-CoA and glycogenic intermediates; therefore, they can be used for both ketogenesis and gluconeogenesis.

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Classification Based on Metabolism (Glucogenic/Ketogenic ) and Nutritional requirement (Essential/Non essential)

 

Glucogenic

Ketogenic

questions.text: An elderly lady presented to the clinic following a head injury. She exhibited an unsteady drunk-like gait while entering the examination room. She also had nodding movements of the head and nystagmus. Which region of the cerebellum marked in the following image was most likely affected by the bleed?
questions.solution:
Area marked as 4 is most likely affected by the bleed, i.e., vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe).

Cerebellum has three parts based on function.

  • Vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe): This lobe is the oldest part of the cerebellum. It has vestibular connections concerned with equilibrium and eye movements. Therefore, in lesions of the flocculonodular lobe, patients will have gait ataxia, nodding of the head and axial body (known as titubation), and nystagmus.
  • Spinocerebellum: This is the region that receives proprioceptive inputs from the body as well as from the motor cortex. By comparing plan from the motor cortex with performance, it smoothens and coordinates movements that are ongoing.
  • Cerebrocerebellum: This is the newest part of the cerebellum. They coordinate with the motor cortex in planning and programming movements. Patients will have dysmetria, dysarthria, dysdiadochokinesis, hypotonia, or intention tremor in one or both extremities. 

Lesions in the cerebellum may present with the following symptoms:

  • Wide-based, drunk-like unsteady, stumbling gait, which is also called staggering gait
  • Ataxia - Defects in movement and coordination
  • Dysdiadokinesia - Inability to perform alternating movements (e.g. supination, pronation) at a fast pace
  • Dysequilibrium - Loss of balance
  • Nystagmus
  • Intention tremor - This tremor is not present during rest, but is present during voluntary movements of limbs. The tremor increases when it reaches the target object of its movement.
  • Speech - Slurred or scanning
  • Hypotonia

Related Pearl: Functional divisions of the cerebellum

  Dorsal Spinocerebellum Ventral Spinocerebellum Cerebrocerebellum (neocerebellum) Vestibulocerebellum (flocculonodular lobe) 
Constituents Vermis (except the nodulus) The adjacent medial portion of the hemisphere The lateral portion of hemispheres Nodulus and flocculus 
Afferent (input) Somatosensory from the trunk, visual, auditory, and vestibular Somatosensory input from the limbs From the cerebral motor cortex, premotor, and somatosensory cortex  Vestibular input, visual input, somatosensory from the neck
Efferent (output) Via Fastigial nucleus to the medial descending system Via interposed nucleus to lateral corticospinal and rubrospinal systems Via dentate nucleus to motor, premotor and prefrontal cortex  To vestibular nuclei in the brain stem (direct projection)
Functions    

Maintains posture and helps in the execution of gross movements

It controls the interplay between agonist and antagonist group of muscles

 Controls the  distal muscles of the limbs (smoothens and coordinates movements) Planning the sequence of voluntary movements    

 Participates in maintaining equilibrium and posture

 

Controls ocular movements

It is responsible for regulating the stability of the head and body in space

questions.text: A female patient comes to you with complaints of midline neck swelling. You proceed to perform the thyroid examination and ask her to swallow. The thyroid mass moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by which of the following fascia?

choices.text: Investing layer of the deep cervical fascia

questions.solution:
The thyroid mass moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by the pre-tracheal fascia.

Pre-tracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. Pretracheal fascia is attached to the larynx and this attachment is responsible for the movement of the enlarged thyroid gland on deglutition.

The ligament of Berry, also called the suspensory ligament extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid. It is formed by the condensation of the pre-tracheal fascia. Its attachment prevents the thyroid gland from sinking down into the mediastinum.

Related Pearl: Modifications of Deep cervical fascia

The deep fascia in the neck is condensed to form the following layers:

Investing layer - It forms the roof of the posterior triangle and splits to enclose:

  • Parotid gland
  • Submandibular gland

Pretracheal fascia - It splits to enclose the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. This capsule is thickened posteriorly and on either side forms the suspensory ligament which is known as the ligament of Berry.

Carotid sheath - is formed anteriorly by pre tracheal fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia. It encloses:

  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve 

Prevertebral fascia - It forms the floor of the posterior triangle and the axillary sheath. Inferiorly, it blends with the anterior longitudinal ligament.

Buccopharyngeal fascia - It covers the outer surface of the pharyngeal constrictors and the buccinator. Posteriorly, it's separated from the prevertebral fascia by the retropharyngeal space.

Pharyngobasilar fascia - It fills the gap between superior constrictor and base of the skull.

questions.text:
The following three MR images of the head taken in the sagittal plane are given to you. Match the image to the MR imaging technique used.
  1. T1 weighted
  2. T2 weighted
  3. STIR
  4. FLAIR
questions.solution:
Image 1 - T2 weighted MRI, image 2 - T1 weighted MRI, and image 3 is a STIR MRI.

By altering the sequence of pulses and the scanning parameters, different properties of the tissue can be assessed. These properties are referred to as the weighting of the scan. T1-weighted images and T2-weighted images are two types of imaging sequences with differences in image contrast.

T1 weighted images:

  • Fluid appears dark (blood, edema, CSF)
  • Fat appears white

T2 weighted images:

  • Fluid appears white 
  • Fat appears dark

STIR- Short tau inversion recovery or short TI inversion recovery

  • Inversion recovery time is short and is used to null signal from fat.
  • Fat appears dark
  • Highly sensitive to detect musculoskeletal disease, degenerative changes, MS lesions, and vertebral metastasis
  • More prone to motion artifacts. Therefore not used in the imaging of the thoracic spine

FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery):

  • It is a T2 weighted sequence with a long inversion recovery time that suppresses signals from the fluid.
  • Fluid appears dark
  • Fat appears dark
  • Motion artifacts in CSF are removed

 

Note: CT can be differentiated from MRI depending on the appearance of bone. Bones appear white on CT, whereas, they appear dark on MRI.

The image below shows a CT scan of the neck (cervical bones appear white):
